articles.headline: ‘It’s More Than I Imagined’: Boeing’s New C.E.O. Confronts Its Challenges
articles.snippet: In a candid interview, David Calhoun largely laid the blame for the company’s 737 Max crisis on his predecessor.
articles.abstract: In a candid interview, David Calhoun largely laid the blame for the company’s 737 Max crisis on his predecessor.
articles.lead_paragraph: FLORISSANT, Mo. — In his eight weeks on the job, Boeing’s chief executive, David L. Calhoun, has come to one overriding conclusion: Things inside the aerospace giant were even worse than he had thought.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and David Gelles

articles.headline: ‘Almost Without Precedent’: Airlines Hit Hard by Coronavirus
articles.snippet: The effects could wipe out up to $113 billion in worldwide revenues this year, a trade group said, a new blow to the industry.
articles.abstract: The effects could wipe out up to $113 billion in worldwide revenues this year, a trade group said, a new blow to the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Empty jumbo jets arriving at deserted airports. Masked passengers disinfecting their own seats. Stone-faced airline executives huddling with President Trump.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: Judge Calls Barr’s Handling of Mueller Report ‘Distorted’ and ‘Misleading’
articles.snippet: The judge said the attorney general lacked credibility on the matter and said he would review the report to decide whether to make its redacted portions public.
articles.abstract: The judge said the attorney general lacked credibility on the matter and said he would review the report to decide whether to make its redacted portions public.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Thursday sharply criticized Attorney General William P. Barr’s handling of the report by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, saying that Mr. Barr put forward a “distorted” and “misleading” account of its findings and lacked credibility on the topic.

articles.headline: ‘It’s Pure Panic’: A Wrenching Wait at Nursing Home Where Coronavirus Took Hold
articles.snippet: Cut off from their relatives inside a virus-stricken nursing center, families are frantically searching for help and basic information.
articles.abstract: Cut off from their relatives inside a virus-stricken nursing center, families are frantically searching for help and basic information.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIRKLAND, Wash. — The hardest day of Debbie de los Angeles’s life had been the day she put her mother into a nursing home. That was before coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Karen Weise and Mike Baker

articles.headline: Was It Always Going to Be the Last Men Standing?
articles.snippet: For Elizabeth Warren, the historic number of women in the 2020 field and the Democrats who supported them, the question will linger.
articles.abstract: For Elizabeth Warren, the historic number of women in the 2020 field and the Democrats who supported them, the question will linger.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the end, the pink wave carried two white men ashore.

articles.headline: As Bernie Sanders Pushed for Closer Ties, Soviet Union Spotted Opportunity
articles.snippet: Previously unseen documents from a Soviet archive show how hard Mr. Sanders worked to find a sister city in Russia when he was a mayor in the 1980s. Moscow saw a chance for propaganda.
articles.abstract: Previously unseen documents from a Soviet archive show how hard Mr. Sanders worked to find a sister city in Russia when he was a mayor in the 1980s. Moscow saw a chance for propaganda.
articles.lead_paragraph: YAROSLAVL, Russia — The mayor of Burlington, Vt., wrote to a Soviet counterpart in a provincial city that he wanted the United States and the Soviet Union to “live together as friends.”
